In chapter 2 of The Giver, Jonas begins his first day of training as the new Receiver of Memory. He meets his mentor, the current Receiver of Memory, who is an old man with pale eyes like Jonas's. The old man gives Jonas his first memory, which is of sliding down a snowy hill on a sled. Jonas experiences the joy and thrill of this memory, but he is also confused by it because he has never experienced snow or sleds before. The old man explains that he is the only one in the community who has access to memories of the past, and that it is his job to transfer those memories to Jonas so that he can help the community make better decisions. Jonas learns that the old man is in pain and takes medication to help him deal with the memories he holds. Jonas leaves the session feeling overwhelmed but also excited to learn more about the past.
Give me three quotes from chapter 3 that show Jonas's character development.

Here are three quotes from chapter 3 of The Giver that show Jonas's character development:

1. "For the first time, he heard something that he knew to be music. He heard people singing. Behind him, across vast distances of space and time, from the place he had left, he thought he heard music too. But perhaps, it was only an echo."

This quote shows that Jonas is beginning to develop a deeper appreciation for things that he has never experienced before, like music. He is starting to realize that there is more to life than what he has been taught in his community.

2. "But the future was what lay ahead, and he wanted to take the journey, even though he did not know what it might bring."

This quote shows that Jonas is becoming more curious and adventurous. He is willing to take risks and explore new things, even if it means leaving his comfort zone.

3. "The thought gave him a feeling of pleasure. He had never felt anything like it before. It was fun to be out in the evening, out in the night, with the wind, moving fast, with no worries or cares."

This quote shows that Jonas is beginning to experience emotions that he has never felt before, like pleasure and joy. He is starting to enjoy the simple things in life and appreciate the beauty of nature.
Give quotes from the novel which illustrate these points.

Here are some quotes from The Giver that illustrate the differences between Jonas's view of himself and the committee's view of him in chapters 7-8:

Jonas's view of himself:

1. "He felt such love for Asher and for his parents. But he knew that even if he begged for his own release, it wouldn't matter. The decision was not his." (Chapter 7)

This quote shows that Jonas is beginning to realize that he is different from his peers, and that he has no control over his own fate. He is feeling emotions that no one else seems to feel, and he is starting to question the rules and traditions that govern their lives.

2. "It's just that... without the memories it's all meaningless." (Chapter 8)

This quote shows that Jonas is starting to see the limitations of his society. He is realizing that without the memories of the past, life is dull and unfulfilling. He is beginning to question the wisdom of a society that denies its citizens access to knowledge and experience.

The committee's view of Jonas:

1. "He has shown us all that he has the potential to become a Receiver. And he has been given an unprecedented level of trust." (Chapter 7)

This quote shows that the committee sees Jonas as a model citizen who is excelling in his training. They are impressed with his intelligence and his ability to grasp complex concepts quickly.

2. "He has the potential to become one of our most respected leaders." (Chapter 7)

This quote shows that the committee sees Jonas as someone who will go on to do great things for the community and uphold its values and traditions. They see him as a potential leader who will maintain the status quo.

3. "We have given you a great honor, Jonas." (Chapter 8)

This quote shows that the committee sees Jonas's training as a privilege and an honor. They view him as someone who has been entrusted with a great responsibility, and they expect him to use his knowledge and skills to serve the community.
In the world of The Giver, What role does love play in the creation of families in the community? Refer to quotes in chapter 6.

In the world of The Giver, love does not play a role in the creation of families in the community. Instead, family units are created through a process of matching, which is based on a number of factors including personality, interests, and intelligence. Love and romantic attraction are not considered important in the formation of these family units.

Here are some quotes from chapter 6 that illustrate this point:

1. "Spouses were matched at the Ceremony of Twelve, and that they went on to have two children, one male and one female, each one born to them by a Birthmother who would never see it. The community was concerned with sameness and uniformity."

This quote shows that the process of matching is the primary means by which families are created in the community. The community values sameness and uniformity over individuality and personal choice.

2. "The matching of Spouses was very carefully done to ensure that children would be produced with the best possible combination of genes. The Committee of Elders studied the health, intelligence, and interests of each adult."

This quote shows that the process of matching is based on a scientific analysis of each person's traits and characteristics. Love and emotional compatibility are not considered important factors in the selection process.

3. "Families were always created in this way, by choosing the best match from among a broad group of candidates."

This quote reinforces the idea that families are created through a process of selection rather than through personal choice or romantic attraction.

Overall, in the world of The Giver, the creation of families is seen as a practical and scientific process, rather than an emotional or romantic one. Love and personal relationships are not considered important factors in the formation of family units.
